title: Footballers in Spain's top women's division to go on strike - putting at risk Man City's Champions League decider against Atletico
text:
Manchester City's last-16 Champions League decider against Atletico Madrid next week could be under threat, after footballers in Spain's top women's division announced strike action on Tuesday.

After 13 months of talks with the Association of Women's Football Clubs (ACFF) aiming to secure players a collective bargaining agreement, last night almost 200 of the women's football union members attended a meeting in which they decided they had had enough. Ninety-three per cent voted in favour of the strike, which they say will last until a CBA is agreed upon.

According to Spanish law the two parties must meet once more in a last-ditch effort to secure an agreement, and from then the player's union will have five days to alert the clubs and the Spanish ministry for employment that they intend to strike. That leaves City's away Champions League last-16 second leg against Atletico Madrid, due to take place on October 30, in jeopardy. Former City player Toni Duggan, now at Madrid, was not present at the meeting on Tuesday night.

Central to the dispute was the players' wish to be recognised contractually as full-time professionals, rather than the part-time, 20-hour agreement the ACFF has put forward.

“We have spent more than a year negotiating, have had 18 meetings and negotiations have stagnated," Athletic Club footballer and vice president of the Association of Spanish Footballers (AFE) Women's Committee, Ainhoa ​​Tirapu said.
description: Manchester City's last-16 Champions League decider against Atletico Madrid next week could be under threat, after footballers in Spain's top women's division announced strike action on Tuesday.
